October 5, 2003: Fiction
BLEACHERS, by John Grisham. (Doubleday, $19.95.) A former star quarterback
returns to his Southern hometown after he learns that his high school coach, a
local legend, has a terminal illness.
THE DA VINCI CODE, by Dan Brown. (Doubleday, $24.95.) The murder of a
curator at the Louvre leads to a trail of clues found in the work of Leonardo and to
the discovery of a centuries-old secret society.
THE WEDDING, by Nicholas Sparks. (Warner, $23.95.) A man tries to regain his
wife's love; a sequel to "The Notebook."
REMEMBER WHEN, by Nora Roberts and J. D. Robb. (Putnam, $25.95.) Writing
as herself and as J. D. Robb, Roberts combines a romance novel set in Maryland
with a police procedural featuring Lt. Eve Dallas.
THE TEETH OF THE TIGER, by Tom Clancy. (Putnam, $27.95.) In the company
of his cousins, the son of President Jack Ryan embarks on a career as a
counterterrorist agent.
THE NAMESAKE, by Jhumpa Lahiri. (Houghton Mifflin, $24.) Tracing the fortunes
of a Bengali-American, Gogol Ganguli, whose parents settled in Cambridge,
Mass., after immigrating from Calcutta.
DUNE: THE MACHINE CRUSADE, by Brian Herbert and Kevin J. Anderson.
(Tor/Tom Doherty, $27.95.) A prequel to Frank Herbert's science fiction series.
FATAL TIDE, by Iris Johansen. (Bantam, $24.95.) A marine researcher who
knows the truth about a deadly mystery finds herself the target of a killer.
THE TIME TRAVELER'S WIFE, by Audrey Niffenegger. (MacAdam/Cage, $25.) A
young woman marries a man who suffers from Chrono-Displacement Disorder,
which sends him back and forth in time.
THE LOVELY BONES, by Alice Sebold. (Little, Brown, $21.95.) A girl looks down
from heaven as she describes the aftermath of her kidnapping and murder.
THE DEVIL WEARS PRADA, by Lauren Weisberger. (Doubleday, $21.95.) A
young woman acquires a job at a fashion magazine, along with the boss from hell.
THE CURIOUS INCIDENT OF THE DOG IN THE NIGHT-TIME, by Mark
Haddon.(Doubleday, $22.95.) A 15-year-old autistic savant sets out to solve the
mystery of a neighbor's dead poodle.
HIGH DRUID OF SHANNARA: Jarka Ruus, by Terry Brooks. (Del Rey/Ballantine,
$27.95.) The first volume in a fantasy series.

Non-Fiction
LIES (AND THE LYING LIARS WHO TELL THEM), by Al Franken. (Dutton,
$24.95.) A satirical critique of the rhetoric of right-wing pundits and politicians.
MADAM SECRETARY, by Madeleine Albright with Bill Woodward. (Miramax,
$27.95.) A memoir by the former secretary of state and ambassador to the United
Nations.
THE GREAT UNRAVELING, by Paul Krugman. (Norton, $25.95.) A volume of
essays, most from The New York Times, that are "mainly about economic
disappointment, bad leadership and the lies of the powerful."
BENJAMIN FRANKLIN, by Walter Isaacson. (Simon & Schuster, $30.) A
biography of the scientist, inventor, writer and Revolutionary statesman.
THREE WEEKS IN OCTOBER, by Charles A. Moose and Charles Fleming.
(Dutton, $23.95.) The former chief of police in Montgomery County, Md., relives
the serial-sniper case.
SHUT UP & SING, by Laura Ingraham. (Regnery, $27.95.) The political
commentator attacks the "elites" of Hollywood, Washington and New York.
LIVING HISTORY, by Hillary Rodham Clinton. (Simon & Schuster, $28.) A memoir
by the junior senator from New York and former first lady.
WHY AMERICA SLEPT, by Gerald Posner. (Random House, $24.95.) An
examination of 9/11 and the United States' failure to prevent it.
THE BOUNTY, by Caroline Alexander. (Viking, $27.95.) A new account of the
1789 mutiny, calling into question the supposed villainy of Captain Bligh and the
vaunted heroism of Fletcher Christian.
AFTER LIFE, by John Edward with Natasha Stoynoff. (Princess, $23.95.) The
television personality and professed psychic offers "answers from the other side."
UNDER THE BANNER OF HEAVEN, by Jon Krakauer. (Doubleday, $26.) The
author of "Into Thin Air" explores the implications of the murder of a woman by two
religious fundamentalists (her brothers-in-law).
TREASON, by Ann Coulter. (Crown Forum, $26.95.) The lawyer and pundit
dissects "liberal treachery from the cold war to the war on terrorism."
KATE REMEMBERED, by A. Scott Berg. (Putnam, $25.95.) Memories from a
writer who was a close friend of Katharine Hepburn's in her last 20 years.
MOUNTAINS BEYOND MOUNTAINS, by Tracy Kidder. (Random House, $25.95.)
A portrait of Dr. Paul Farmer, who divides his time between Harvard and Haiti,
where he works to relieve the suffering of the poor.
